review: Got a strange blue screen "content unavailable " for the 1st two days I had it but had sound in all my movie apps on the stick.Took a ton of trouble shooting, port cleanings, power cyvles to just get it started. Had to shuffle the stick around in my home hdmi ports and power cycle it multiple times in order to finally see a show. Additionally to truly power cycle it I had to physically remove it from the port after unplugging the power supply as opposed to just unplugging the adapter. It would nit restart unless i did so. A real nuisance for my wall mounted LTD and Plasma. Had it for 3 days now and will amend review as updates come along. It's a "beta" stick for them so I hope for a more stable solution or off to Chrome I go.

review: This device performs well on my Sony Bravia that has only one HDMI port.  Amazon advertising was misleading when it advertised just plug the stick into the HDMI port.  You need a power source to plug into. This was very difficult in our case as our TV is housed in an entertainment unit. Tense moments ensued when we learned we needed another LONG extension cord to plug it in as everything was fed to the back of the unit.  The lack of an APP for Acorn TV  was disappointing. I have Apple TV and I can at least do the mirroring with my iPad for Acorn TV.

review: For the price, the device is good, but there are some performance issues that hinder the experience. Sometimes the device will hang for a few odd seconds when transitioning. The device also froze on us within 30 minutes out of the box. Also the device has a very steep learning curve due to the odd menu layout. Amazon needs to figure out how to make an easy user interface because as it stands, the Fire TV interface is a pain.However, when you get down to it, the Fire TV Stick does what it says it does and offers content from multiple sources.
